article: "Ms Ashley, I want to be in your group!" the statement that excited eight-year-old Skye had changed my life, as we boarded the bus last Friday. It was the big summer _ to the Georgia Aquarium, and I had fallen victim to fifty hyperactive kids. Although I was not _ to chaperoning field trips, riding on a school bus for three hours was a first. _ by Game Boys, MP3 players, and fifty totally different _ , I sat down with the noisy kids on the bus, the seven-and eight-year-olds. Having already built a _ with most of the kids eased the _ , but today a new kid, Skye, joined the group. Since I went to public school in the fifth grade, I've stood in an empty room of quiet walls. _ in this room, I could withdraw from everything and no one _ . Skye was the only one of the kids that was often labeled as the _ child. If all the kids _ me, Skye would be the one to oppose. I _ it, but he pulled me out of my comfort zone without even _ it. I realized my defining moment was created. _ he kept the group away from me with his childish nature, his leadership _ me. Everything he did pulled and _ dragged me out of my lifelong corner. Skye _ the seven-and eight-year-olds to drive me _ that Friday, but one simple statement, "Ms Ashley, I want to be in your group," turned the trip from a(n) _ to a dream come true. That trip became the _ one of my life. I have become someone who is not _ to be a leader or voice the opinions that have laid within me for years, and Skye is the reason.
